headline: Great experience, however shift to corporate structure at expense of employees
pros: Ability for exposure to complex funds. Gain visibility and experience in full lifecycle of the fund and entire workflow, including daily cash transactions, quarterly close, capital activity, and waterfall exposure.
cons: Compensation is is below market. Promotions within organization are frequent which is fantastic, but comp doesn't follow - almost as if giving out titles in lieu of paying internally developed employees a fair market value. Move towards corporate structure with new leadership seems to have devalued past contributions and employees who have been there for awhile.

headline: This is for the office in luxembourg. Run!!
pros: 34.5 holidays due to banking convention, city centre.
cons: Promotion is not based on performance but whether you are not seen as a competition. Management are condescending to lower level staff or make them feel undervalued. Their version of growth is employing senior people outside and not promoting internally as these people are needed exactly where they are.  Very high level of turnover-  3 whole teams left and are being rebuilt. Management focus on short term issues instead of making changes for long term and better prospects. The truth is being distorted and reported to the New York office. Management is deluded and running this office to the grounds as the wrong people are being trusted.

headline: Company has potential but BEWARE of some teams
pros: helpful & friendly peers, great for learning fund accounting, become friends with co-workers when you stay late together, grow with company
cons: Company as a whole is decent, but there are some bad apple (teams). Some teams have high turnover rates; they are high for a reason. Compensation for fund accountant and seniors is low in the industry. The hours are long and only get longer if they realize you are good at your job. Manager gossiped about former employees to discourage team from quitting (note, this did not work). There was a micromanaging culture - checking employee status for login/logout time, and away time for lunch breaks. Office politics is strong.

headline: Investor Services is Neglected
pros:
- Nice office, great location in Midtown
- Accounting teams seemed close knitted and friendly
- Can work from home (My supervisor did it weekly but it was frowned upon when Analysts did)
cons:
- Services team is very stagnant with little emphasis on management/growth
- Directors/Supervisors come and go (Poor indication of turnover) 
- A LOT of down time. Work only seems to pick up when it is time to leave, and you'll have to stay for a task which could have been done earlier if management was on top of the workload. 
- Although, quarter end time usually means staying till Midnight or later due to the lack of team members.
- Little to no room for promotion (2 years at the company doing the same tasks everyday is easy to leave when there is no monetary compensation.
- Could not talk/joke with my sole team member -- Was told to "look busy" because higher ups walks around.
-It is a great company, Investor Services was a bad experience.

headline: A whole team left

headline: Run away, toxic environment
pros: You get 19 business days off during a year, which includes your sick and personal days altogether
cons: Pretty toxic environment, if the manager doesn’t like you, they will make your life pretty miserable. They can accuse you for the stuff you never did, give bad/false feedback on purpose, humiliate. The managers are full of themselves. Never been unhappy in my life.

headline: Great company, shamefully misrepresented here.   The negative reviews are erroneous or old
pros:
Small company positive aspects, with incredible growth.
-  Many of the reviews are incredibly old, company doubled in size recently and got new departments/new HR/Training/etc.
-  Most negative posts on here are complaining about too much work, welcome to Accounting, you'll work twice the hours at a Big 4 (I've worked at both)
cons: Nothing major, slight growing pains from small to big company

headline: Rapid expansion

Rapidly expanding company.

headline: Fund Accountant
pros:
Hire entry-level accounting people. 
Paid overtime. 
Assign a company buddy to new hire.
Most of managers are professional (a few of them are not)
Summer Friday, you can leave at 3pm
cons:
The company doesn't care about individuals. You are on your own. 
Office environment is too quite, no one talks. 
Give little training, and expect you do a perfect job.

headline: Unprofessionalism
pros: None, nice pantry and good sugar coating during interview
cons: Communism, inability to freely express and speak to management about operational flow. Weak training process

headline: Worst experience of my life
pros: very few. You get to learn basic accounting
cons: Horrible MD’s with no accountability for themselves. They do not care for their employee’s only about themselves. Staff and senior’s do all the work and the mangers get all the credit. You’re just a number to them. Very little training but they expect you do be perfect

headline: It's the usual deal...All up to YOU!
pros: Most people are professional, dedicated, intelligent, and ambitious. Great culture - it's small company so you get to know everyone pretty quickly and form good relationships. You learn a lot very fast. If your attitude is "this is just a job", look elsewhere. Expectations are set high, so be ready to give your full effort.
cons: Little room to make mistakes, You get sucked into caring too much and feeling responsible for each process.  Experience will depend on who you report to, Benefits/Time Off is not the best compared to other firms, but could be flexible at times.

headline: Meh. There are better places out there.
pros: Best reason to work here would be that they heavily hire entry level candidates that can't find anything better and equip them with great fund accounting knowledge.
cons: The challenges here really depend on who your manager and clients are. As long as you meet your deadlines and get your work done, they don't give you a hard time. The benefits they offer leave a lot to be desired.

headline: Every man for himself!
pros: Enjoyed the other staff members, growing firm
cons: Cut corners on cost, high expectations but little to no training, do not care about employees as individuals only about company performance, not a collaborative environment

headline: Gen II is a professional place to work and to learn.
pros: Still need longer to give a better opinion.
cons: Not much for now. Everything looks fine.
